title: Changed Hive validation to make it compatible with old Hive version with auth turned on, and Hive query generation compile with new Hive version
body:
Changed Hive validation to make it compatible with old Hive version with auth turned on, and Hive query generation compile with new Hive version:
- Changed Hive conversion validation job to make use of filesystem instead of resultset to make it work with ancient Hive versions that do not play with delegation tokens refer: HIVE-14015
- Tests to check if Hive queries are being generated with backticks at correct places, to compile with new Hive versions
- Changed Hive query generator to apply backticks as restricted by new Hive versions while maintaining backward compatibility

title: Make sure maven central repo is first; bug fixes
body:
- We've been seeing gobblin-core failures on Travis. It seems related to aws-java-sdk-1.7.4 being needed by hadoop-aws . It seems like the artifact was being pulled from jcenter rather than Maven Central and there might be an issue with the former. I've reordered the repositoriy registration so Maven comes first.
- I think I've finally figured out an issue with intermittently failing :gobblin-compaction:test . MRCompactorJobRunnerFilenameRecordCountProviderTest was creating a directory under source code tree which was confusing gradle. Moved the directory to /tmp/
- Added log4j configuration for gobblin-rest-server tests to write test output to /tmp/gobblin-rest-server-test.log . Hopefully that helps with intermittent failures.

@abti can you review ?

title: Change Hive Avro to ORC publish to use Gobblin constructs instead of Hive exchange partition query
body:
Change Hive Avro to ORC publish to use Gobblin constructs instead of Hive exchange partition query: 
- Hive exchange partition query was being used to move partitions from staging to final table
- However, this can fail queries in flight because the current model overwrites data location
- To overcome this, we have changed the publish module to use Gobblin constructs 

New publish works as follows: 
- Staging table partition is created in a directory under Gobblin control (dir name prefix is derived from source partition location string; such as if partitionDir.prefixLocationHint is set to 'hourly,daily' and 'hourly' exists as substring in source partition path, then 'hourly' string is prefixed to dir name of the partition) 
- At the time of publish, first the staging partition directory is moved as ORC final table sub directory (if previously any dir existed, its deleted; however here hourly / daily hint helps)
- Previous partition is dropped if any from the destination table, and new partition is created with new partition directory location
- Old partition directory (if different) is left over for retention to clean up

Also, other minor changes: 
- Each staging partition gets it own staging table 
- Code refactoring

title: Fix for HIVE-11194: exchange partition does not work properly if data directory for destination partitions pre-exists
body:
If a partition is being exchanged into a table but the data directory location for the partition already exists, Hive moves data within a sub-directory of it rather than cleanly overwriting it.

More details here: HIVE-11194

So, adding a pre publish hook to cleanup the existing directory (if any) of an existing partition in destination table before issuing exchange partition from staging to destination.

repo.name: gobblin

title: Made changes to handle Hive-6129 (inverted exchange partition bug) and corresponding support for backward incompatible changes in Hive
body:
Made changes to handle Hive-6129 (inverted exchange partition bug) and corresponding support for backward incompatible changes in Hive: 
- Hive-4095 introduced the partition exchange feature for first time in v0.12
- HIVE-6129 found out that the advertised behavior was inverse (source was being treated as target and vice-versa) and a backward incompatible fix was introduced

So, changed Gobblin code to handle all versions of Hive by taking hint from config about the Hive version and creating the correct corresponding Hive statement 

Also, added a few javadocs

In Hive v0.13, Hive does not support fully qualified Hive table names such as db.table for table rename. So, changed publish commands to specify 'use dbName' as a precursor to the rename

title: Hive Based Retention
body:
- Added time based retention for hive partitions.
- In the context of hive retention a `Dataset` is a `Table` and a `DatasetVersion` is a `Partition`
- `AbstractHiveDatasetVersionFinder` and its subclasses can be used outside of retention as well.
- Moved some common logic from `MultiVersionCleanableDatasetBase` to `FsCleanableHelper` as it needs to be used by the `CleanableHiveDataset` too.
- Added tests

repo.description: A distributed data integration framework that simplifies common aspects of big data integration such as data ingestion, replication, organization and lifecycle management for both streaming and batch data ecosystems.

title: Added Azkaban job that can validate conversion result by comparing source and target Hive tables
body:
Added Azkaban job that can validate conversion results by comparing source and target Hive tables: 
1. Job first discovers all the tables configured for conversion 
2. Then it checks if any conversion was performed on that source table (by checking the update time)
3. If there are any new conversions, the job generates query to compare the two tables or partition (source and destination)
4. The job finishes off by reporting the result of comparison of all datasets converted recently

title: Added limit clause to Hive query generation to enable conversion validation of sample subset
body:
Added limit clause to Hive query generation to enable conversion on sample data size for validation purposes

With this addition, to run a job that runs sampled conversion on multiple datasets: 
1. Use BackfillHiveSource
2. Configure rest of Avro to ORC conversion job as you normally would 
(by specifying dataset whitelist, etc)
3. Set rowLimit to a low number (say 1)
4. Run the job

title: Support for schema evolution, staging, selective column projection and compatibility check for Avro to ORC
body:
Adding support for:
- Schema evolution: Support to evolve destination ORC table for changes in source table schema (Hive / ORC does not support evolution yet, this is being added with hope that Hive / ORC will soon support evolution)
- Staging: Support to first stage converted data in a staging table before publishing / committing it to the final table
- Selective column projection: To counter against schema evolution on source hive table, this feature would help selectively project columns from source that are in destination / ORC table

title: Gobblin on AWS
body:
## Introduction

This PR enables Gobblin to run in cluster mode on AWS via a new sub-module called `gobblin-aws` 
- `gobblin-aws` provides support to launch and run Gobblin cluster on AWS 
- `gobblin-aws` inherits from `gobblin-cluster` to make use of its abstraction wrapping Helix clustering capabilities 
- `gobblin-aws` performs all AWS resource management activities and provides for other critical cluster management capabilities not already provided by `gobblin-cluster` such as: High Availability, Elasticity and Failover
## Architecture

![gobblin-on-aws-architecture](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/69499/16608965/e094b320-4304-11e6-8352-a4d6a7031d25.png)
### AWS Cluster Launcher

`gobblin-aws` is launched using `GobblinAWSClusterLauncher` which upon bootup launches a few services: 
- `AWSClusterSecurityManager` to authenticate with AWS and refresh credentials at configured intervals
- `AWSSdkClient` to coordinate with AWS and launch various resources 

After this, the `GobblinAWSClusterLauncher` computes the cloud-init scripts as well as AWS LaunchConfigurations and requests AWS to launch two `AutoScalingGroups*`:
- Master `AutoScalingGroup` to launch and manage EC2 instances for `GobblinAWSClusterMaster` 
- Workers `AutoScalingGroup` to launch and manage EC2 instances for `GobblinAWSTaskRunner` 
### Master AutoScalingGroup

When an EC2 instance under Master `AutoScalingGroup` boots up, it executes the master cloud-init script that:
- First, creates a `NFS` server and setups work environment on the node (eg. creating all relevant directories) 
- Second, launches a java application to run `GobblinAWSClusterMaster` with relevant classpath and JVM arguments 

The `GobblinAWSClusterMaster` upon bootup: 
- Registers itself as HelixController for the cluster
- Launches a few services:
- 1. `AWSJobConfigurationManager` that runs on configured frequency and polls for new or updated job configurations from S3
- 2. `GobblinHelixJobScheduler` that schedules discovered new or updated jobs for execution
### Workers AutoScalingGroup

When n-number of EC2 instances under Workers `AutoScalingGroup` boot up, they execute worker's cloud-init script that: 
- First, mounts the `NFS` shared directory by master and setups work environment on the node
- Second, launches a java application to run `GobblinAWSTaskRunner` with relevant classpath and JVM arguments 

The `GobblinAWSTaskRunner` upon bootup: 
- Registers itself as a HelixParticipant in the cluster 
- Registers `GobblinHelixTaskFactory` to listen to Helix and process any tasks 

**AutoScalingGroup**\* `AutoScalingGroup` is a service provided by AWS in which:
- Users can specify minimum, maximum and desired number of instances
- Scaling criteria based on which `AutoScalingGroup` automatically launches new instances or shuts them down to scale for load OR launch new instance if any instance dies. 

Note: 
1. When new instance launch, they execute the configured cloud-init script and hence register themselves as master or workers
2. `AutoScalingGroup`s help us achieve HA and Elasticity for load 
### Execution Model

Gobblin cluster on AWS makes use of Helix [Distributed Task Execution Framework](http://helix.apache.org/0.7.1-docs/recipes/task_dag_execution.html) to schedule and run jobs. 
For each Gobblin job run: 
- The `GobblinHelixJobScheduler` on Master node starts a `GobblinHelixJobLauncher` that wraps the Gobblin job into a `GobblinHelixJob` and each Gobblin Task into a `GobblinHelixTask`, which implements the Helix's Task interface so Helix knows how to execute it 
- The `GobblinHelixJobLauncher` on Master node then submits the job to a Helix job queue named after the Gobblin job name, from which the Helix Distributed Task Execution Framework picks up the job and runs its tasks through the live participant worker nodes 
## Upcoming / Pending
- Replace `NFS` with `EFS` which recently went into GA 
- Multi master support for master HA 
- Support for spot instances 
- More hooks for auto scaling rules / parameters 
- Task execution JVM isolation (though this needs to be baked into `gobblin-cluster` )
- `AMI` for AWS to bootup from a pre-baked Gobblin instance 
- Process watcher daemon running on all nodes (master and workers) to restart `GobblinAWSClusterMaster` and `GobblinAWSTaskRunner` process JVMs if they die 
## Running Gobblin-on-AWS

Follow these steps to run Gobblin-on-AWS 
- Build Gobblin as you build today, and extract the distribution tar.gz 
- Modify `conf/aws/application.conf` as described later in `Configuration` section 
- Replace secret and access keys with dummy values in `application.conf` and upload it on S3 
- Launch Gobblin cluster on AWS by running: `bin/gobblin-aws.sh start` 

A private key file with pem extension should be saved on the disk, you can use this to ssh into Master and Worker nodes as you would in any regular instance on AWS 
### Configuration

Getting started with Gobblin on AWS is easy. Only the following configurations need to be changed in `conf/aws/application.conf` :

```
# Cluster name
gobblin.aws.cluster.name=GobblinAWSPullRequest

# Zookeeper connection string
# Note: You can use the example below, but the example Zookeeper may or may not be available
# Example: gobblin.cluster.zk.connection.string="ec2-54-149-223-115.us-west-2.compute.amazonaws.com:2181"
gobblin.cluster.zk.connection.string="ec2-54-149-223-115.us-west-2.compute.amazonaws.com:2181"

# AWS Credentials
gobblin.aws.service.access="<AWS Access Key>"
gobblin.aws.service.secret="<AWS Secret Key>"

# Leave as-is for sample wikipedia pull job
# -- OR --
# Specify S3 URI for job configuration:
# Steps to obtain this URI:
#1. Create a S3 folder in a bucket, say the bucket name is "s3bucket" and folder is "/gobblin-confs/job-conf/"
#2. Zip your pull files in a zip and upload to this folder. Say your zip file name is myPullFiles.zip
#3. Specify S3 URI for this zip file in the config below
#    For the description above: "https://s3-region.amazonaws.com/s3bucket/gobblin-confs/job-conf/myPullFiles.zip"
gobblin.aws.job.conf.s3.uri="https://s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/gobblin-libs/job-config/wikipedia.zip"

# Specify S3 URI for cluster configuration
# Steps to obtain this URI:
#1. Create a S3 folder in a bucket, say the bucket name is "s3bucket" and folder is "/gobblin-confs/cluster-conf/"
#2. After editing this application.conf: upload this application.conf, log4j-aws.properties and quartz.properties to
#    /s3bucket/gobblin-confs/cluster-conf/
#    Note: Make sure to replace AWS credential values with dummy values.
#          We don't read AWS credentials from application.conf in S3
#3. Specify S3 URI for this folder in the config below
#    For the description above: "https://s3-region.amazonaws.com/s3bucket/gobblin-confs/cluster-conf/"
# Example: gobblin.aws.master.s3.conf.uri="https://s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/gobblin-libs/cluster-config/"
gobblin.aws.master.s3.conf.uri="https://s3-region.amazonaws.com/s3bucket/gobblin-confs/cluster-conf/" 
```
## Notes
- **Logs** for master and workers are saved in a common directory in `NFS` and are available in real time
- All classes in this PR have been marked with `Alpha` tag, although they have been tested thoroughly several times 
- No change is required in the way `Metrics` or any jobs are configured 
- More documentation will follow in Wiki PR

title: Add support for nested and flattened orc conversion configuration
body:
## Changes 1. Added support for nested and flattened orc conversion configuration in `ConvertibleHiveDataset` 2. The `ConvertibleHiveDataset` supports any number of destination conversion formats each with it's own `ConversionConfig`.
3. A `ConversionConfig` has a `destinationTableName`, `destinationDbName`, `destinationDataPath` and a few optional configs like `numBuckets`, `clusterBy`, `runtimeHiveProps` 4. The constructor of `ConvertibleHiveDataset` takes in a dataset Config which MUST have a comma separated list of destination formats at key, `destinationFormats` 5. `ConversionConfig` for a format can be set by using this destination format as prefix. 6. E.g. If `destinationFormats=flattenedOrc,nestedOrc`
The destination table name for flattened ORC is set at `flattenedOrc.tableName`
And the destination table name for nested ORC is set at `nestedOrc.tableName` Design doc - https://docs.google.com/document/d/1IH9XzY93wiDf6-rzRuFuC6KZSOufulpQSCP5O9eSUUU/edit#heading=h.q4hfu3do5xv3 **Enable both flattened ORC and Nested ORC conversion for a dataset** 
hive.conversion.avro : {
  
  ## Both flattened and nested are enabled for this dataset. 
  ## (This can be any format string. The string here should match the prefix in the 
  ## next section)
  destinationFormats=flattenedOrc,nestedOrc

  ## Flattened orc configs
  flattenedOrc : {

    ## Required
    destination.tableName="$TABLE_flattenedOrc"
    destination.dbName="$DB_flattenedOrcDb"
    destination.dataPath="/tmp/data_flattenedOrc/$DB/$TABLE"
    
    ## Optional
    clusterByList=c1,c2
    numBuckets=4

    ## Each of these hive properties are set before executing the conversion queries **
    hiveRuntime : {
      hive.merge.mapfiles=false
      mapred.map.tasks=10
    }
  }

  ## Nested orc configs
  nestedOrc : {

    destination.tableName="$TABLE_nestedOrc"
    destination.dbName="$DB_nestedOrcDb"
    destination.dataPath="/tmp/data_nestedOrc/$DB/$TABLE"
    clusterByList="c3,c4"
    numBuckets=5

    hiveRuntime : {
      mapred.map.tasks=12
    }
  }
}
**The same configuration can also be set with job props when config store is is not setup** 
hive.conversion.avro.destinationFormats=flattenedOrc,nestedOrc

hive.conversion.avro.flattenedOrc.destination.tableName=$TABLE_flattenedOrc
hive.conversion.avro.flattenedOrc.destination.dbName=$DB_flattenedOrcDb
hive.conversion.avro.flattenedOrc.destination.dataPath=/tmp/data_flattenedOrc/$DB/$TABLE
hive.conversion.avro.flattenedOrc.clusterByList=c1,c2
hive.conversion.avro.flattenedOrc.numBuckets=4
hive.conversion.avro.flattenedOrc.hiveRuntime.hive.merge.mapfiles=false
hive.conversion.avro.flattenedOrc.hiveRuntime.mapred.map.tasks=10

hive.conversion.avro.nestedOrc.destination.tableName=$TABLE_nestedOrc
hive.conversion.avro.nestedOrc.destination.dbName=$DB_nestedOrcDb
hive.conversion.avro.nestedOrc.destination.dataPath=/tmp/data_nestedOrc/$DB/$TABLE
hive.conversion.avro.nestedOrc.clusterByList=c3,c4
hive.conversion.avro.nestedOrc.numBuckets=5
hive.conversion.avro.nestedOrc.hiveRuntime.mapred.map.tasks=12
@abti can you review if you are getting bored? :)

title: Added CURRENTMINUTE and CURRENTSECOND options for watermark cutoff
body:
When watermark type is TIMESTAMP, we wanted to extract data up to past few seconds or minutes. But there were only CURRENTDATE and CURRENTHOUR cutoff options. So I added CURRENTMINUTE and CURRENTSECOND to AppendMaxLimitType.
Can someone please review and accept this feature?

repo.description: A distributed data integration framework that simplifies common aspects of big data integration such as data ingestion, replication, organization and lifecycle management for both streaming and batch data ecosystems.

title: Updating the README and other outdated docs to encourage use of Gobblin Releases
body:
- Many users try to get started with Gobblin by building the code (e.g. `./gradlew build`), then un-tarring the resulting `gobblin-distribution.tar.gz` file, and then running the Wikipedia example
  - Many of them fail to get the build working, or have problems running the tests
- Most of our documentation suggests getting started with Gobblin by first building it (e.g. the `README.md` and Getting Started Guide both suggest this)
- However, users should just be using the releases here: https://github.com/linkedin/gobblin/releases rather than building the latest code themselves
- This PR updates the `README.md` file and a few other docs to encourage first time users to use the releases rather than building the code themselves
- I also uploaded the `gobblin-distribution.tar.gz` file for the latest release (0.7.0)
  - Going forward I think each release should also have the `gobblin-distribution.tar.gz` file attached, so that users can download it directly rather than building it themselves

title: Oracle Source/Extractor
body:
Created OracleSource.java and OracleExtractor.java with heavy inspiration from MySqlSource.java and MySqlExtractor.java.

The classes are largely the same as the MySql ones with the exception of getSchemaMetadata() which needed to be modified to account for Oracle reserved words such as format and comment. Also timestamp formats had to be slightly refactored.

Further different strategies for handling primitive values like booleans in Oracle needed to be accounted for. This resulted in overriding getSchema(). The only difference is that Oracle treats booleans as varchar2(1). I created a simple casting utility castToBoolean() which I added to SqlQueryUtils.java.

Since getSchema requires use of the private static final Gson factory from JDBCExtractor. I created a getter for access. It is accessed in OracleExtractor's getSchema() method like so: this.getGson()

I am able to successfully complete table_append and table_full jobs using this new source and extractor. I did a clean assemble, and it did not break the build. I believe I stayed consistent with documentation and coding format.

Please consider my pull request, and let me know if I need to change anything.

Thanks!
Brian Vanover

P.S. One thing is that in order to use the Oracle source and extractor, ojdbc6.jar must be added as a dependency. I simply copied the jar into goblin-dist/lib, but it may be worthwhile to add it as a dependency. I just wasn't sure how to modify the build scripts to include it.

title: Add ConvertibleHiveDataset and config store support to HiveDatasetFinder
body:
1. Added `ConvertibleHiveDataset` used in conversion jobs 2. Added support for reading dataset configs from gobblin config store if available. If config store is not configured, job configs with a prefix are used as dataset config. By default the prefix is empty string. But by setting `hive.dataset.configPrefix` only configs with this prefix is passed to the `HiveDataset`'s``` `datasetConfig`.
**Some Example**
**a. Retention jobs** 
hive.dataset.configPrefix=hive.dataset.retention
hive.dataset.retention.is.blacklisted=true
hive.dataset.retention.selection.policy=blah
`CleanableHiveDataset` will be initialized with 
is.blacklisted=true
selection.policy=blah
**b. Avro to Orc Conversion jobs** 
hive.dataset.configPrefix=hive.dataset.conversion.avro.orc
hive.dataset.conversion.avro.orc.is.blacklisted=true
hive.dataset.conversion.avro.orc.destination.tableName=blah
`ConvertibleHiveDataset` will be initialized with 
is.blacklisted=true
destination.tableName=blah
Note that `is.blacklisted` is a key in local scope which is used to blacklist a dataset in any context. @ibuenros and @abti can you review? Here is the [design doc](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1IH9XzY93wiDf6-rzRuFuC6KZSOufulpQSCP5O9eSUUU/edit#heading=h.q4hfu3do5xv3)

repo.name: gobblin
repo.description: A distributed data integration framework that simplifies common aspects of big data integration such as data ingestion, replication, organization and lifecycle management for both streaming and batch data ecosystems.

title: Initial commit for hive retention
body:
Implementation of hive retention. It uses `HiveCleanableDatasetFinder` to find `HiveCleanableDataset`. Each `HiveCleanableDataset` will contain `HiveTablePartitionVersions`. If a table is not partitioned, it will be single version. Otherwise, it will contain partitions as versions. 
Currently, there are two retention policies. One is `HiveTablePartitionInvalidDataLocRetentionPolicy`, which is based on if the data location exists on filesystem. Another one is `HiveTablePartitionTimeBasedRetentionPolicy`, which is based on some timestamp. Now the default behavior is based on modified timestamp. But it can be overridden. 

Tested on holdem, I have created RB: https://rb.corp.linkedin.com/r/756706/ for sample job configs I used.

title: Disable flattening for complex types other than nested records and union
body: Disable flattening for complex types other than nested records and union, since ORC does not support predicate pushdown for complex types, so even if we flatten nested structure within a map or array - it will not help and complicates conversion process.

title: MR launcher does not write tasks to the jobstate file in HDFS.
body: This PR reduces the size of job.state file by not serializing all of the tasks there, as the mappers read their tasks from separate files either way. This reduces required memory for the mappers.

repo.description: A distributed data integration framework that simplifies common aspects of big data integration such as data ingestion, replication, organization and lifecycle management for both streaming and batch data ecosystems.

title: Make kafka buffer size configurable
body:
As mentioned in the mailing list, the existing gobblin configuration means that if any topic configured to have a larger buffer size than the default of 1mb will silently fail to be consumed when a large message is read. The silence is mostly Kafka's fault, but Gobblin should be able to be to support topics with large messages through a configuration parameter.

I am sending this as a preliminary patch, expecting you guys might have problems with it, because to be fair, the situation is a bit tricky: The KafkaOldAPI is the piece that needs this configuration, but it receives no configuration information.

Given that this is theoretically different by topic (although for some reason, KafkaTopicMetaData won't produce this information), I thought it really should be handled as something done by topic, although, for the time being, I am feeding the data from the work unit.

For the call that we make to get the list of kafka topics, I am using the defaults instead, because it doesn't seem like a place where one would change message topics, and trickling that up to a point that can read the configuration seems like quite a few changes.

I'd be happy to take a different approach, but then I'd like guidance on what would make the PR approvable.
